awd_titl_txt: TWC SBE: TTP Option: Medium: Collaborative: EPICA: Empowering People to Overcome Information Controls and Attacks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies the security of representative personalized services, such as search engines, news aggregators, and on-line targeted advertising, and identifies vulnerabilities in service components that can be exploited by pollution attacks to deliver contents intended by attackers.

This project also develops defense-in-depth countermeasures against pollution attacks. These include new server-side mechanisms to prevent the various cross-site-request-forgery schemes that allow an attacker to insert actions. The defense mechanisms also include a distributed data collection, measurement and analysis framework to detect anomalies in browsing behaviors and information contents that are indicative of pollution of user profiles or population preferences. The new information analysis techniques use machine learning and natural language processing to identify differences (e.g., missing information) that are significant or important to a user. The project also develops tools to alert users and guide them to understand and repair profiles, and studies regulatory models to incentivize the industry to adopt a more transparent practice.

This project develops an evaluation framework to facilitate the development and adoption of technologies. The evaluation plan includes user studies involving real, diverse user groups on the Internet.

To transition technologies to practice, this project makes the tools freely available, and deploys data collection and measurement systems on the Internet. This project also educates users about pollution attacks and engages with users to improve the usability of the tools.

por.por_cntn:
The underlying algorithms of Internet information services rely on inputs from the open environment, the Internet, that provides opportunities for attackers to compromise the integrity of input data and affect the output. Indeed, new attacks are emerging in which attackers are polluting users’ individual profiles or generating large-scale user behaviors and hence fake preferences to affect the information contents delivered to users. These are serious threats to our society, for example, with falsified information served to users they can compromise the integrity of e-commerce and even our political process.

The EPICA project studied the security of representative personalized services, such as Google Search, news aggregators, and on-line targeted advertising, and identified vulnerabilities in service components that can be exploited by pollution attacks to deliver contents intended by attackers. The EPICA project also developed defense-in-depth countermeasures against pollution attacks. These include new server-side mechanisms to prevent the various cross-site-request-forgery schemes that allow an attacker to insert actions, a distributed data collection, measurement and analysis framework to detect anomalies in browsing behaviors and information contents that are indicative of pollution of user profiles or population preferences, and tools to allow users to protect privacy when browsing the Web or using IoT devices.

The main research activities and resulting technologies and findings are:

  • Studies of manipulations attacks and abuses in on-line advertising. This project showed a new ad fraud mechanism that enables publishers to increase their ad revenue by deceiving the ad exchange and advertisers to target higher paying ads at users visiting the publisher’s site. This attack is based on polluting users’ interest profile by issuing requests to content not explicitly requested by the user such that it influences ad selection. This project found that there is serious privacy leakage in targeted mobile apps. In particular, there is statistically significant correlation between observed ads and the user’s profile, e.g., gender and parental status.
  • Development of Bobble. This project developed a collaborative filtering system called Bobble to detect and defend against search profile poisoning. Bobble highlights the difference of search results between a user and the other participating users. It can also display sentiment difference (e.g., inexpensive vs. expensive goods, or left-leaning vs. right-leaning political views). A user can then decide if his search results are likely due to search profile poisoning and if so purge the injected searches from his search profile due to a poisoning attack. Bobble has been downloaded tens of thousands of times and several thousands active users.
  • Development of user privacy protection mechanisms. This project developed TrackMeOrNot, an open-source anti-tracking mechanism to allow users to selectively share their on-line behaviors with vendors. This project also developed Appu, which is available for free download, to help users keep track of their password reuse, password strength, password stagnancy, and privacy footprint so that they can better manage the security and privacy risks due to reusing the same password among different sites and devices.
  • User study. This project conducted user studies and found that users are unaware that information manipulation can occur in Google search, tools like Bobble do assist users in detecting information manipulation and learning more about personalization; and users require tools like Bobble to alert them when information manipulation or pollution of their profile has occurred.

This project has resulted in several papers published in the top security, machine learning, and networking conferences, as well as the freely available Bobble and Appu, and the open-source TrackMeOrNot. Many information manipulation attacks can be abstracted as poisoning the input of a machine learning based systems. Therefore, the principles, techniques, and systems on detecting and mitigating information manipulation developed in this project contribute to the important research area of adversarial machine learning.

The results from this project have been integrated into security curriculum at Georgia Tech.  For example, profile poisoning attack is now taught in the graduate-level Network Security course. Several Ph.D. students have worked this project; in particular, two had completed their thesis research in this project and are now tenure-track faculty members.
